Title: Beatrice Rana and LSO perform Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5 in E-Flat Major (Full Performance)
Description:
Beatrice Rana plays Beethoven's grand "Emperor" Concerto with the London Symphony Orchestra and conductor Gianandrea Noseda.

00:06 I. Allegro
20:50 II. Adagio un poco mosso
29:22 III. Rondo: Allegro ma non troppo

Listen to more music by Beatrice Rana here: https://lnk.to/ranaLY

Though the appellation "Emperor" was not given by the composer himself, this concerto was born during a time of military influence: the Napoleonic Wars. Beethoven began writing the work in 1808 and completed it in 1809 in Vienna, the same year that the city came under siege by Napoleon's army. Due to the composer's then-severely declining hearing, the concerto was premiered by soloist Friedrich Schneider, rather than by Beethoven himself, in 1811.

Filmed in February 2022 at the Barbican Centre, London.

Title: E. KISSIN - G. NOSEDA - S. RACHMANINOV Piano Concerto n. 3 Op. 30 - live in Rome 2023
Description:
üëâLISZT Consolation No. 3
https://youtu.be/IL9BRgmieeg?si=fuItKjCRNKP2jGOF

üëâBEETHOVEN "F√ºr Elise"
https://youtu.be/92AmgPlWvdw?si=b4oKgv68tu974fmJ

üëâRendano Piano Concerto
https://youtu.be/_ETRizPEXsw?si=BYgFch7hF-S4s-iR

It's surrounded by an aura of legendary technical difficulty, thanks in part to the film "Shine," the Concerto No. 3 in D minor for Piano and Orchestra by Sergei Rachmaninoff, known as the "Rach3." In the film, the protagonist Geoffrey Rush, playing the pianist David Helfgott, descends into madness due to the spasmodic tension caused by performing this piece. In the concert, it is performed by Evgeny Kissin, described as "one of the most admired pianists of our time for the intensity and sensitivity of his interpretations," as noted by the New York Times.

On the podium is the Milanese conductor Gianandrea Noseda, a regular guest at the Santa Cecilia concerts since 1999 and currently the Music Director of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington and the General Music Director of the Opernhaus in Zurich, awarded in 2022 by German critics with the "Oper! Award" as the "Best Orchestra Conductor."

Title: Haydn Symphony No 90 C major Gianandrea Noseda
Description:
The Symphony No. 90 in C major, Hoboken 1/90, was written by Joseph Haydn in 1788 as part of a three-symphony commission by Comte d'Ogny for the Concerts de la Loge Olympique. It is occasionally referred to as The Letter R -- referring to an older method of cataloguing Haydn's symphonic output.
Gianandrea Noseda 
1. Adagio - Allegro assai, 3/4 0:00
2. Andante, 2/4 6:40
3. Menuetto: Allegretto, 3/4 13:28
4. Finale: Allegro assai, 2/4 18:14
The second movement is in double variation form.
The finale contains one of Haydn's more famous jokes. Soon after the recapitulation starts, the music arrives at a rousing and unexpected "ending" in C major followed by four measures of silence which leads the audience to believe the symphony may have actually finished. Instead, the first theme quietly resumes in the remote key of D-flat major.

Title: Liszt : Prometheus (Gianandrea Noseda / Orchestre national de France)
Description:
Plac√© sous la direction du chef Gianandrea Noseda, l'Orchestre national de France interpr√®te le po√®me symphonique Prometheus, compos√© par Franz Liszt en 1850.

En 1802, quelques mois avant sa mort √† cinquante-neuf ans, le po√®te, th√©ologien et philosophe Johann Gottfried Herder pr√©senta son drame Der entfesselte Prometheus (¬´ Prom√©th√©e d√©livr√© ¬ª), m√™lant r√©cits mythologiques (dans la continuit√© de l‚Äôantique Prom√©th√©e encha√Æn√© d‚ÄôEschyle, dont il subsiste les fragments d‚Äôun Prom√©th√©e d√©livr√©), mais aussi r√©f√©rences chr√©tiennes. ¬´ Le Prom√©th√©e herd√©rien n‚Äôest nullement le r√©volt√© des heures tumultueuses du Sturm und Drang, mais le symbole de l‚Äôhomme d√©sireux de se lib√©rer de lui-m√™me, de se d√©passer vers une perfection toujours plus haute. Il n‚Äôest pas davantage une abstraction, mais un personnage bien individualis√©, malgr√© sa port√©e all√©gorique : l‚Äôantique Titan respire bien, dans l‚Äô√¢me de Herder, un souffle nouveau ¬ª, √©crit Raymond Trousson.

Ma√Ætre de chapelle √† la cour de Weimar depuis deux ans, Liszt fut charg√© en 1850 d‚Äô√©crire la musique de sc√®ne d‚Äôune unique repr√©sentation de cette pi√®ce. Il composa les principaux motifs musicaux au printemps, et en confia pendant l‚Äô√©t√© √† son secr√©taire Joseph Joachim Raff l‚Äôassemblage et l‚Äôorchestration. Outre la partie instrumentale, des ch≈ìurs faisaient entendre moissonneurs, vignerons, oc√©anides, tritons, na√Øades et autres cr√©atures des mondes souterrains. Liszt fera publier s√©par√©ment ces ch≈ìurs en 1855 (ils conna√Ætront un grand succ√®s jusqu‚Äô√† la fin du XIXe  si√®cle, et on peut les entendre dans un enregistrement Hungaroton de 1972). Apr√®s l‚Äôajout de sa touche finale, Liszt dirigea lui-m√™me les musiciens le 24 ao√ªt 1850, et une statue de Herder, toujours visible sur la Herderplatz de Weimar, fut inaugur√©e.

De 1852 √† 1854, Liszt retravailla son ≈ìuvre en retirant les parties chorales, pour en faire son cinqui√®me po√®me symphonique, sous le titre Prometheus. De nouveau, il se chargera d‚Äôen diriger la cr√©ation, cette fois √† Brunswick, le 18 octobre 1855. Une comparaison de la musique de sc√®ne et du po√®me symphonique montre pour la premi√®re une ¬´ version Raff ¬ª harmoniquement plus dissonante, mais pour le second une ¬´ version Liszt ¬ª rythmiquement plus agressive. Rappelons que le Titan Prom√©th√©e, ayant vol√© le feu aux dieux de l‚ÄôOlympe pour le donner aux hommes, fut condamn√© √† √™tre encha√Æn√© √† un rocher, son foie √©tant d√©chiquet√© par un aigle. L‚Äôorgane reprenant forme chaque lendemain, le supplice recommen√ßait perp√©tuellement. Ce sont ces souffrances que Liszt √©voque au d√©but de la partition avec empilement de quartes, chromatismes, th√®mes saccad√©s, accords sombres. Puis une fugue (la partie la plus travaill√©e de l‚Äô≈ìuvre) expos√©e par les cordes, ouvre le d√©veloppement de ce qui s‚Äôapparente √† une forme sonate. Ce sont les cors qui feront appara√Ætre le motif de la r√©demption du h√©ros lib√©r√© de ses entraves par H√©racl√®s.

Title: Ludwig van Beethoven: Overture, Leonore No 3 // Gianandrea Noseda and the London Symphony Orchestra
Description:
Principal Guest Conductor Gianandrea Noseda conducts the LSO in Beethoven's Leonore No 3 Overture recorded live in concert at the Barbican in London on 20 June 2024. 

Beethoven wrote no fewer than four punchy overtures for his only operatic work. Number three was rejected for being a miniature opera in itself. Leonore, eventually renamed Fidelio, follows a courageous wife who rescues her beloved husband from prison.

#LondonSymphonyOrchestra #beethoven  #overture

Title: Maurice Ravel Piano Concerto in G major | Piemontesi, Noseda, EUYO
Description:
March 7th, 2023 would have been Maurice Ravel‚Äôs 148th birthday. To celebrate, we invite you to listen to one of his last works ‚Äì the Piano Concerto in G major. According to the composer himself, the piece was supposed to be ‚Äúa genuine concerto, (...) clearly highlighting the soloist‚Äôs virtuosity,‚Äù modeled after Mozart and Saint-Sa√´ns. 

18th Chopin and his Europe International Music Festival
In the Year of Polish Romanticism
14-31 August 2022

23 August 2022
Tuesday, 21:00
Warsaw Philharmonic Concert Hall

Francesco Piemontesi piano
Gianandrea Noseda conductor
European Union Youth Orchestra

Jak deklarowa≈Ç sam kompozytor, dzia≈Ço mia≈Ço byƒá ‚Äûprawdziwym koncertem, (...) wyra≈∫nie podkre≈õlajƒÖcym wirtuozeriƒô solisty‚Äù, wzorowanym na kompozycjach Mozarta i Saint-Sa√´nsa.

The Kennedy Center‚Äôs Concert Hall, Washington, D.C., USA / Sep. 24, 2022 
NSO's Season Opening Gala Concert 
Broadcast on WETA Classical with Bill Bukowski and Nicole Lacroix on Sep. 28, 2022

11:15 Variation 15: Pi√π vivo scherzando (F major)
12:23 Variation 16: Allegretto (B‚ô≠ minor)
14:08 Variation 17: (Allegretto) (B‚ô≠ minor)

21:04 Variation 22: Marziale. Un poco pi√π vivo (Alla breve)

23:52 Variation 24: A tempo un poco meno mosso (A minor ‚Üí A major) 
      24:44 Dies Irae 

25:08 Applause 

26:49 Maestro Noseda Talks about Daniil 


WETA Classical's blog article by Nicole Lacroix: 

"[...] When Daniil Trifonov played the Rachmaninoff from memory, it was as if his soul and body were directly connected to the music and it just poured out of him‚Äîthe easiest thing in the world. His performance‚Äîalthough that‚Äôs not the right word: it was more a heart-to-heart sharing of what was in his deepest being‚Äîwas by turns exciting, uber romantic and devilishly difficult. It felt like he was channeling Paganini, that legendary virtuoso who made the ladies swoon. 

Afterwards, my seat neighbor and I jumped to our feet and turned to each other in excitement. ‚ÄúStunning,‚Äù we both exclaimed. [...]"

https://weta.org/fm/classical-score/waltzing-noseda-and-other-highlights-nso-season-opening-gala-concert 


Michael Andor Brodeur's review: 

"[...] Trifonov at the piano to deliver a "Rhapsody" brimming with color, complexity and, as befits its two-dozen variations on Paganini's theme, multiple personalities.
It was a pleasure to see and hear Trifonov is his element. I last heard him was here in the Concert Hall, but under the vastly different circumstances of May 2021. 

[..] 

He's that rare virtuoso whose skills seem to swirl around a sound sense of humor - drifting through its dizzying cadenzas with the ease of a daydream, banging out its "Dies Irae" intrusions with the corrective bark of a headmaster. Trifonov and the orchestra were also keenly locked, navigating stormy syncopation, militaristic buildups and outbursts of heated dialogue with grace and ferocity. [...]"

https://www.washingtonpost.com/music/2022/09/25/national-symphony-season-opener-noseda/

Title: Rimski-Korsakov : Sh√©h√©razade (Gianandrea Noseda / Orchestre national de France)
Description:
Structure : 
00:00 1. La mer et le vaisseau de Simbad (Largo e maestoso - Allegro non troppo)
10:02 2. Le r√©cit du prince Kalender (Lento - Andantino - Allegro molto - Con moto)
22:29 3. Le jeune prince et la jeune princesse (Andantino quasi allegretto - Pochissimo pi√π mosso - Come prima - Pochissimo pi√π animato)
32:50 4. F√™te √† Bagdad - La Mer - Le Vaisseau se brise sur un rocher surmont√© d'un guerrier d'airain (Allegro molto - Vivo - Allegro non troppo maestoso)

C‚Äôest √† l‚Äôorientaliste Antoine Galland, sujet du roi Louis XIV, que l‚ÄôEurope doit la d√©couverte et la premi√®re traduction du recueil des contes orientaux Les Mille et une nuits. Secr√©taire de l‚ÄôAmbassadeur de France √† Istanbul, Galland s‚Äôinspira non seulement des textes et r√©cits qu‚Äôil avait recueillis au Proche-Orient, mais aussi des contes de Mme d‚ÄôAulnoye, dont la Laideronnette sera plus tard illustr√©e par Ravel dans Ma M√®re L‚ÄôOye. La fortune des Mille et une nuits conna√Ætra de nouveaux regains gr√¢ce aux traductions plus fid√®les de l‚Äôanglais Richard Francis Burton en 1888 (ann√©e de composition de la suite symphonique de Rimski-Korsakov) et du franco-√©gyptien Joseph-Charles Mardrus √† la toute fin du XIXe si√®cle.

Interrompant l‚Äôorchestration de l‚Äôop√©ra Le Prince Igor de son ami Borodine r√©cemment d√©c√©d√©, Rimski-Korsakov √©crivit rapidement Sh√©h√©razade avec cet argument : ¬´ Le sultan Schahriar, persuad√© de la fausset√© et de l‚Äôinfid√©lit√© des femmes, avait jur√© de faire donner la mort √† chacune de ses femmes, apr√®s la premi√®re nuit. Mais la sultane Sh√©h√©razade sauva sa vie en l‚Äôint√©ressant aux contes qu‚Äôelle lui raconta pendant la dur√©e de Mille et une nuits. Press√© par la curiosit√©, le sultan remettait d‚Äôun jour √† l‚Äôautre le supplice de sa femme, et finit par renoncer compl√®tement √† sa r√©solution sanguinaire. Bien des merveilles furent racont√©es √† Schahriar par la sultane Sh√©h√©razade. Pour ses r√©cits, la sultane empruntait, aux po√®tes leurs vers, aux chansons populaires leurs paroles, et elle intercalait les r√©cits et les aventures les uns dans les autres. ¬ª

Dans son Journal de ma vie musicale, Rimski-Korsakov ne cachait pas son embarras devant la n√©cessit√© de donner un titre pr√©cis aux quatre mouvements de son ≈ìuvre, au risque de restreindre l‚Äôimagination de ses auditeurs : ¬´ C‚Äôest en vain que l‚Äôon cherche des leitmotive toujours li√©s √† telles images. Au contraire, dans la plupart des cas, tous ces semblants de leitmotiv ne sont que des mat√©riaux purement musicaux du d√©veloppement symphonique. Ces motifs passent et se r√©pandent √† travers toutes les parties de l‚Äô≈ìuvre, se faisant suite et s‚Äôentrela√ßant. Apparaissant √† chaque fois sous une lumi√®re diff√©rente, dessinant √† chaque fois des traits distincts et exprimant des situations nouvelles, ils correspondent chaque fois √† des images et des tableaux diff√©rents. Ainsi le motif vigoureusement dessin√© de la fanfare de trombone et de trompette avec sourdine, qui appara√Æt pour la premi√®re fois dans le r√©cit de Kalender (2e  partie) appara√Æt de nouveau, dans la 4e  partie, √† la description du vaisseau qui se brise, quoique cet √©pisode n‚Äôait aucun lien avec le r√©cit de Kalender. ¬ª

A voir : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fC1oPZFsFdE&t=4s par Anne-Charlotte R√©mond

Musicopolis : Rimski-Korsakov √† Saint-P√©tersbourg
https://www.radiofrance.fr/francemusique/podcasts/musicopolis/rimski-korsakov-a-saint-petersbourg-en-1888-1-5-2456950

Quelle est la meilleure version de Sh√©h√©razade ?
https://www.radiofrance.fr/francemusique/podcasts/la-tribune-des-critiques-de-disques/sheherazade-de-rimski-korsakov-4114375

Title: Shostakovich, Piano Concerto No. 1
Description:
Daniil Trifonov @daniiltrifonov , William Gerlach
National Symphony Orchestra @kennedycenter / Gianandrea Noseda - 
Dmitri Shostakovich: Piano Concerto No. 1, Op. 35 (1933) 

00:00 Intro 
00:11 I. Allegro moderato
06:40 II. Lento
15:01 III. Moderato
16:41 IV. Allegro con brio

The Kennedy Center‚Äôs Concert Hall, Washington, D.C., USA / May 28, 2021 


Michael Andor Brodeur‚Äôs Review: 

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell you how excited we onstage are to see you here,‚Äù Kennedy Center president Deborah Rutter said from the stage of the Concert Hall on Friday night, moments ahead of a long-awaited reunion between the NSO and its audience.

(Well, 32 of the former and 236 of the latter, in an auditorium that seats nearly 2,500.) 

The feeling was clearly mutual among the eager listeners who had gathered, spaced out across the hall in pairs and separated from each other by long gaps and dead rows.

The hundreds of empty seats felt like a steady, silent signal throughout the evening that while the arts are evidently ‚Äúback,‚Äù their return is fraught, actively contending with their own fragility. In some ways, the increased exclusivity necessitated by reasonable caution feels like a precipice all its own. [‚Ä¶] 

Trifonov brought his now-distinct balance of brute force and beauty (frequently showcased on ‚ÄúSilver Age,‚Äù his most recent recording of works by Stravinsky, Prokofiev and Scriabin), but augmented it with a detectable extra dollop of menace.

Noseda‚Äôs handling of the Lento movement guided its gentle surges of color ‚Äî through which William Gerlach‚Äôs steady co-star of trumpet shot like a beam of dawn ‚Äî and its brushes with silence. Taking the movement into his own hands, Trifonov slowed the tempo to the point you thought the music might break.

Shostakovich‚Äôs punchlines and interjections seemed more barbed and sarcastic in Trifonov‚Äôs hands, and he attacked the cadenzas of the rollicking finale with stormy alternations of fleet-fingered ease and furious typing. Gerlach admirably kept pace with the finale‚Äôs rapid-fire finish ‚Äî which felt like a wake-up call in the middle of the evening.

(Overheard at intermission: ‚ÄúBoy, that Shostakovich sure is growing on me.‚Äù) [‚Ä¶]  

https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/national-symphony-orchestra-review-first-with-live-audience/2021/05/29/51ce020a-c0a3-11eb-b26e-53663e6be6ff_story.html 


A review on TASS: 

But here in America, for me this is the first concert with an orchestra after [the start of] the pandemic,‚Äù Trifonov confirmed. In December 2020, the musician played a solo concert on stage in Florida in the presence of an audience. [...] 

In an interview with a TASS correspondent a couple of years ago, he revealed plans to prepare a cycle of songs for baritone and piano based on poems by Vladimir Nabokov, Joseph Brodsky and Arseny Tarkovsky. When asked to say how things are going with this work, Trifonov replied: ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt finished it yet. Other ideas have appeared, and I put this project aside for now.‚Äù 

https://tass.ru/kultura/11506691

Title: Stravinsky : Scherzo fantastique (Gianandrea Noseda / Orchestre national de France)
Description:
Plac√© sous la direction de Gianandrea Noseda, l'Orchestre national de France joue le Scherzo fantastique compos√© par Igor Stravinsky entre juin 1907 et mars 1908.

¬´ Qui aura lu ce livre ne sera pas en √©tat de conduire une ruche, mais conna√Ætra √† peu pr√®s tout ce qu‚Äôon sait de certain, de curieux, de profond et d‚Äôintime sur ses habitants. ¬ª Voil√† comment √©tait pr√©sent√©e en 1901 La Vie des abeilles par son auteur Maurice Maeterlinck, futur Prix Nobel de litt√©rature, et p√®re de la pi√®ce Pell√©as et M√©lisande qui inspira nombre de compositeurs. C‚Äôest apr√®s la lecture de cet ouvrage po√©tique et apicole, admir√© notamment par Rilke, que Stravinsky con√ßut en 1907-1908 un Scherzo fantastique, dont le vrombissement initial est une allusion aux pr√©cieux insectes. Il √©crira plus tard dans un fran√ßais remarquable (mais ici l√©g√®rement corrig√©) : ¬´ En √©t√© 1907, je lisais beaucoup de livres sur la vie des abeilles et j‚Äô√©tais fort √©mu par maints d√©tails de la vie de ce monde extraordinaire. Cette vie ininterrompue d‚Äôusine (la ruche) √† travers des g√©n√©rations, et ce vol nuptial de la reine des abeilles, ce meurtre du m√¢le, son amant, dans les hauteurs vertigineuses, cette √©nergie vitale et ce lyrisme f√©roce m‚Äôont servi comme base, soi-disant litt√©raire, pour ce po√®me symphonique, que j‚Äôai intitul√© Scherzo fantastique. La partition d‚Äôorchestre de cet ouvrage √©tait la derni√®re que mon ma√Ætre Nicolas Rimski-Korsakov ait connue de moi. Malheureusement, il ne l‚Äôa jamais entendue √† l‚Äôorchestre, √©tant mort quelques mois avant l‚Äôex√©cution. ¬ª

Informant son ma√Ætre de l‚Äô√©volution de la partition, il lui confia : ¬´ L‚Äôharmonie dans Les Abeilles sera f√©roce, comme une rage de dents, mais aussit√¥t, cela devra devenir plaisant, comme de la coca√Øne. ¬ª Stravinsky gardera plus tard une certaine tendresse pour cette ≈ìuvre de (relative) jeunesse : ¬´ L‚Äôorchestre sonne. La musique est l√©g√®re, d‚Äôune mani√®re qui est rare dans les ≈ìuvres de cette √©poque, et il y a l√† une ou deux bonnes id√©es‚Ä¶ Et en r√©√©coutant la pi√®ce, je regrette de ne pas avoir exploit√© davantage la fl√ªte alto. C‚Äôest malgr√© tout un opus 3 prometteur‚Ä¶ Je vois √† pr√©sent que j‚Äôai emprunt√© quelque chose au Vol du bourdon de Rimski-Korsakov (‚Ä¶), mais le Scherzo doit bien plus √† Mendelssohn, par l‚Äôinterm√©diaire de Tcha√Økovski, qu‚Äô√† Rimski-Korsakov. ¬ª √âtonnante all√©gation de Stravinsky, tant l‚Äôinfluence orchestrale de son ma√Ætre est ici manifeste, tout comme celle de Wagner ! Quoi qu‚Äôil en soit, la cr√©ation √† Saint-P√©tersbourg de cette partition marquera le cours de l‚Äôhistoire de la musique. En effet, ce soir du 6 f√©vrier 1909, outre cinq cents roubles de r√©compense, Stravinsky rencontra Serge de Diaghilev, l‚Äôimpresario des Ballets russes pour lesquels il √©crira L‚ÄôOiseau de feu, P√©trouchka et Le Sacre du printemps. Le Scherzo fantastique fut ainsi l‚Äô√©tincelle qui alluma ce gigantesque brasier.

Le 10 janvier 1917, dans le cadre d‚Äôune caritative ¬´ matin√©e patriotique pour nos combattants des arm√©es de terre et de mer ¬ª, un ballet blanc fut pr√©sent√© √† l‚ÄôOp√©ra de Paris sous le titre Les Abeilles, avec ce Scherzo fantastique chor√©graphi√© par L√©o Staats et dans√© par Carlotta Zambelli. Stravinsky r√©sidait alors en Suisse, √† Morges (o√π il √©crira l‚Äôann√©e suivante son Histoire du soldat), et son autorisation ne fut pas demand√©e, pas plus que celle de Maeterlinck, install√© √† Nice dans une villa baptis√©e‚Ä¶ ¬´ Les Abeilles ¬ª ! Ce dernier r√©clama des comptes, ce qui exasp√©ra le compositeur : ¬´ Les Abeilles de Maeterlinck m‚Äôont (‚Ä¶) consid√©rablement g√™n√©. Un matin √† Morges, j‚Äôai re√ßu une surprenante lettre de lui, m‚Äôaccusant d‚Äôavoir voulu le tromper et l‚Äôescroquer. On avait intitul√© mon scherzo Les Abeilles ‚Äî c‚Äôest le droit de n‚Äôimporte qui de le faire, apr√®s tout, et on en avait tir√© un ballet qu‚Äôon dansait alors √† Paris. Je ne l‚Äôavais pas autoris√© et je ne l‚Äôavais pas vu. ¬ª Voil√† qui est exact, mais qui explique sans doute (avec, en 1917, d‚Äô√©videntes r√©ticences financi√®res sur les droits d‚Äôauteur) sa mauvaise foi lorsqu‚Äôil d√©ment l‚Äôinfluence de l‚Äô√©crivain belge sur sa musique : ¬´ Un peu de mauvaise litt√©rature fut imprim√©e sur la page de garde de ma partition pour satisfaire mon √©diteur qui croyait qu‚Äôune histoire allait faire vendre la musique. ¬ª Le musicien d√©noncera avec √©nergie la ¬´ lettre de M. Maeterlinck, et ses d√©clarations ridicules au sujet de l‚Äôargument des Abeilles ¬ª.

1:35 I. Andante - Allegro con anima 
15:35 II. Andante cantabile con alcuna licenza
27:50 III. Valse. Allegro moderato
33:33 IV. Finale. Andante maestoso - Allegro vivace

ABOUT THE EUROPEAN UNION YOUTH ORCHESTRA
European Union Youth Orchestra: a European success story that the Young Euro Classic audience has followed closely since the festival‚Äôs founding. Time and again, the orchestra, which unites the best young musicians from all the EU states, has gleaned standing ovations at the Konzerthaus. And the EUYO commands not only the best players but has also welcomed the greatest conductors on its podium, whether it was Claudio Abbado, Bernard Haitink, Herbert Blomstedt or this year Gianandrea Noseda

Title: Tchaikovsky: Symphony No. 5 | European Union Youth Orchestra & Gianandrea Noseda
Description:
Pyotr I. Tchaikovsky's 5th Symphony in E minor, Op. 64 in a really young interpretation: It is played by the European Union Youth Orchestra conducted by Gianandrea Noseda. The live recording took place at the Young Euro Classic Festival in 2018 at the Konzerthaus Berlin. This particular concert stands out for the level of skill but also for how much the musicians are obviously enjoying playing their instruments together. You can really feel how much fun they're having.

The European Union Youth Orchestra (EUYO) has existed for more than 40 years. The EUYO brings together the best musicians from all EU countries, aged between 14 and 24. The orchestra's concerts are crowd pullers, not least because the young musicians play with the world's most famous conductors - here with Gianandrea Noseda.

Peter Tchaikovsky's 5th Symphony in E minor is also popular with the public. After his 4th Symphony in 1877, Tchaikovsky initially had no intention of composing another symphony. But more than 10 years later he wrote down his Symphony No. 5 in only a few weeks and then conducted its premiere on November 17, 1888. Right at the beginning of the first movement the so-called fate motif is heard, which becomes characteristic for the entire 5th Symphony. But whether Tchaikovsky's Symphony 5 really pursues the program of a "Schicksalssymphony" is disputed. What is undisputed, however, is the rank that the 5th Symphony occupies among Tchaikovsky's 6 symphonies.

(00:00) I. Andante. Allegro con anima
(14:43) II. Andante cantabile, con alcuna licenza
(26:59) III. Waltz. Allegro moderato
(32:40) IV. Finale. Andante maestoso. Allegro vivace.

https://www.youtube.com/dwclassicalmusic

Title: Ï°∞ÏÑ±ÏßÑ (Seong Jin Cho) Chopin 2 with Gianandrea Noseda and European Union Youth Orchestra
Description: More than 40 years of the European Union Youth Orchestra: a European success story which the Young Euro Classic audience has followed closely since the festivals founding. Time and again, the orchestra, which unites the best young musicians from all the EU states, has gleaned standing ovations at the Konzerthaus. As a special treat, Europes musicians have invited the new shooting star of the piano, Seong-Jin Cho, interpreting Chopins Piano Concerto No. 2.
